histogram.name: Android.Wallet.BoardingPass.Detected
histogram.summary: Records detected flight boarding pass barcode images on each page load. It's only enabled on the Chrome Android app. It's only emitted once on page load, either detected or not detected.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AndroidX.ApiCall
histogram.summary: Records calls to WebView APIs from AndroidX. Some AndroidX-originating calls may plumb through the corresponding platform (framework) API if the device OS version supports the platform API. In this case the API call will be logged by the "Android.WebView.ApiCall" histogram instead. This is logged each time an AndroidX API is called through the "boundary interface" code path (see //android_webview/support_library/README.md for more details).

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AndroidX.MethodCacheEviction
histogram.summary:
This histogram emits true when an entry is evicted from the AndroidX method cache. This histogram never emits false.
This histogram is not expected to be logged, since the cache should be larger than the number of methods in the boundary interface. It exists as a failure detection signal.
This histogram is only emitted when the WebViewCacheBoundaryInterfaceMethods feature is enabled.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AndroidX.MethodCacheGetResult
histogram.summary:
This histograms records whether a lookup for a cached method in the AndroidX boundary interface method cache was a hit or a miss.
The purpose is to measure the effectiveness of the method cache.
This histogram is logged every time a lookup is performed on the method cache, but only when the WebViewCacheBoundaryInterfaceMethods feature is enabled.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AndroidX.Profile.ExtraHeaderAttached
histogram.summary:
This histogram is logged every time a header configured through the AndroidX Profile.setExtraHeaderForOrigins API matches an outgoing request, whether it is the original request or a redirect. The histogram records whether the header was ultimately attached to the request (Used) or skipped because it would have overwritten an existing header on the request (Not Used).
The histogram is emitted once for each matching header on each request or redirect.
The histogram is intended to provide data on how often headers configured through this API collides with existing headers, as input for potential future changes to the AndroidX API.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AndroidX.Profile.ExtraHeaderTargetsCorsPreflight
histogram.summary:
This histogram is logged every time a header configured through the AndroidX Profile.setExtraHeaderForOrigins API matches an outgoing CORS preflight request, and is emitted once per request, even if multiple headers match.
The histogram is intended to provide data on how often headers configured through this API applies to CORS preflight, to inform if and how to handle preflight request.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall
histogram.summary:
Records calls to WebView APIs through the platform (framework) APIs. This may include AndroidX API calls on OS versions where the AndroidX library just calls through the platform API (see "Android.WebView.AndroidX.ApiCall" for details). This is logged each time an API is called.
For historical data (before M99), see "WebView.ApiCall".

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Duration.Framework.LOAD_DATA_WITH_BASE_URL
histogram.summary: How long the WebView loadDataWithBaseURL API takes to run. This measures the sync time the API takes to return not the actual time until the page loads. This is logged only when the app calls loadDataWithBaseURL explicitly.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Duration.Framework.LOAD_URL
histogram.summary: How long the WebView loadUrl API takes to run. This measures the sync time the API takes to return not the actual time until the page loads. This is logged only when the app calls loadUrl explicitly.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Duration.Framework.LOAD_URL_ADDITIONAL_HEADERS
histogram.summary: How long the WebView loadUrl with addtional headers API takes to run. This measures the sync time the API takes to return not the actual time until the page loads. This is logged only when the app calls loadUrl with addtional headers explicitly.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Overridden.WebChromeClient
histogram.summary:
Records which methods of WebChromeClient the caller has overridden when calling WebView.setWebChromeClient. The goal of this histogram is to determine the popularity of the various callback methods present in WebChromeClient.
This histogram is logged every time a WebChromeClient is set.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Overridden.WebChromeClient.Count
histogram.summary:
Records how many methods of WebChromeClient the caller has overridden when calling WebView.setWebChromeClient. The goal of this histogram is to track how many methods apps override to assist the analysis of API usage in WebView.
This histogram is logged every time a WebChromeClient is set.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Overridden.WebViewClient
histogram.summary:
Records which methods of WebViewClient the caller has overridden when calling WebView.setWebViewClient. The goal of this histogram is to determine the popularity of the various callback methods present in WebViewClient.
This histogram is logged every time a WebViewClient is set.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Overridden.WebViewClient.Count
histogram.summary:
Records how many methods of WebViewClient the caller has overridden when calling WebView.setWebViewClient. The goal of this histogram is to track how many methods apps override to assist the analysis of API usage in WebView.
This histogram is logged every time a WebViewClient is set.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.Static
histogram.summary:
Records calls to static WebView APIs through the platform (framework) APIs. This may include AndroidX API calls on OS versions where the AndroidX library just calls through the platform API (see "Android.WebView.AndroidX.ApiCall" for details). This is logged each time an API is called.
Recorded in M118+.
This metric was expired between Aug 2024 and Jan 2025 and may be missing data.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ApiCall.System
histogram.summary:
Records calls to WebView APIs made by the system through the platform (framework) APIs. This is logged each time an API is called.
Recorded in M118+.
This metric was expired between Aug 2024 and Jan 2025 and may be missing data.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AppliedProcessGlobalCacheDirectoryBasePath
histogram.summary: Whether a cache directory base path, provided through the process global config, was applied when loading the WebView library. Recorded once per WebView startup.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AppliedProcessGlobalDataDirectoryBasePath
histogram.summary: Whether a data directory base path, provided through the process global config, was applied when loading the WebView library. Recorded once per WebView startup.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AssetPathWorkaroundUsed.FactoryInit
histogram.summary: In some cases, WebView is unable to find the package ID which usually means that the AssetManager for the Context passed to WebView doesn't have WebView loaded in it. We have a rudimentary workaround for this which is to add WebView's asset path to the Context. Since writing this workaround, we believe we've addressed the underlying problem. Therefore the workaround should no longer be needed. This histogram logs whether the asset path workaround was needed during startup so that we can determine if it's safe to remove. This is logged once during WebViewChromiumFactoryProvider#initialize.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AssetPathWorkaroundUsed.StartChromiumLocked
histogram.summary: In some cases, WebView is unable to find its own Resources which usually means that the host app is doing something unsupported with the Context passed to WebView (or with the platform Resources class). We have a rudimentary workaround for this which is to add WebView's asset path to the Context. Since writing this workaround, we believe we've addressed the underlying problem. Therefore the workaround should no longer be needed. This histogram logs whether the asset path workaround was needed during startup so that we can determine if it's safe to remove. This is logged once during WebViewChromiumAwInit#startChromium.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.Default.Duration.CreateOrLoadFromDisk
histogram.summary:
Records the UI thread blocking time taken to instantiate the default profile, which may or may not already reside on disk.
Emitted once per session at Chromium startup after the immediate UI thread blocking work for instantiating the default profile is completed. Note that profile instantiation may trigger additional tasks, threads, or processes to be started, which may not be measured by this histogram. This non-measured work may still block practical usage of a profile.
Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.Instantiations
histogram.summary:
After a (default or non-default) profile is instantiated (freshly created or loaded from disk), records the new total count of instantiated profiles for the current session. Profiles cannot currently be unloaded, so this reflects the number of profiles actively loaded in memory.
For example, if 3 profiles are started during a session, this histogram will emit 1, then 2, then 3. Note that this means direct modal or percentile based analysis of this histogram is not meaningful.
Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.NonDefault.CountAtStartup
histogram.summary:
The number of non-default profiles listed on disk at WebView startup. This is counted before any profiles are loaded, created, deleted, or otherwise manipulated.
The default profile is not explicitly tracked in the pref_store and as such is not included in the count.
Emitted once per session at Chromium startup.
Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.NonDefault.Duration.Create
histogram.summary:
When a non-default profile is requested and needs to be newly created (it does not previously exist on disk), records the UI thread blocking time taken to create and instantiate the profile.
Emitted once per non-default profile after it is created and sufficiently instantiated to be returned to the getter caller. Note that profile instantiation may trigger additional tasks, threads, or processes to be started, which may not be measured by this histogram. This non-measured work may still block practical usage of a profile.
A single session will never emit both .Create and .LoadFromDisk for the same profile. Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.NonDefault.Duration.Delete
histogram.summary:
Records the time taken to delete an on-disk but uninstantiated non-default profile. Requests to delete instantiated or non-existant profiles will not emit to this histogram.
Emitted once per deleted non-default profile after its deletion is completed.
Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.NonDefault.Duration.LoadFromDisk
histogram.summary:
When an existing non-default profile is requested and needs to be loaded from disk, records the UI thread blocking time taken to load and instantiate the profile.
Emitted once per non-default profile after it is loaded and sufficiently instantiated to be returned to the getter caller. Note that profile instantiation may trigger additional tasks, threads, or processes to be started, which may not be measured by this histogram. This non-measured work may still block practical usage of a profile.
A single session will never emit both .Create and .LoadFromDisk for the same profile. Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.NonDefault.TimeSinceStartup.Create
histogram.summary:
When a non-default profile is requested and needs to be newly created (it does not previously exist on disk), records the time between AwBrowserContextStore initialization and this first request for the profile.
Emitted once per non-default profile creation, just before its registration to the pref_store.
A single session will never emit both .Create and .LoadFromDisk for the same profile. Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.NonDefault.TimeSinceStartup.Delete
histogram.summary:
When a request to delete an on-disk but uninstantiated non-default profile is made, records the time between AwBrowserContextStore initialization and the deletion request. Requests to delete instantiated or non-existant profiles will not emit to this histogram.
Emitted once per deleted non-default profile just before its deletion is started.
Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.NonDefault.TimeSinceStartup.LoadFromDisk
histogram.summary:
When an existing non-default profile is requested and needs to be loaded from disk, records the time between AwBrowserContextStore initialization and this session's first request for the profile.
Emitted once per requested existing non-default profile per session just before the time of its load from disk.
A single session will never emit both .Create and .LoadFromDisk for the same profile. Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwBrowserContext.ProfileDataMigrationHappened
histogram.summary: Records whether or not the default profile migration step runs during its constructor. The primary purpose of this metric is to observe when it is safe to remove the profile migration step.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.AwContentsConstructorTime{IsFirst}
histogram.summary: Time it takes to run the AwContents constructor. Recorded {IsFirst} time the constructor is run.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.CachedFlagMigration
histogram.summary: Records when any experiment is being migrated from manual shared preferences to the generic WebViewCachedFlags implementation. This is recorded once per startup and records true for startups where a migration takes place and false otherwise. We expect to use this metric to determine when to remove the migration code (when no more or a negligble amount of experiments are being migrated).

histogram.name: Android.WebView.CachedFlagsExist
histogram.summary: When we read the cached flags from shared preferences, this histogram records whether we successfully found existing cached flags. The cached flags may not be there if the app/user has cleared the data directory, the app is freshly installed or in some cases when the WebView version changes. This metric does not include the "old manual experiments" referenced in WebViewCachedFlags.java. This metric is recorded once per startup.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.CacheQuotaFreshness
histogram.summary:
Records how this session's cache quota was obtained in `AwBrowserProcess::GetHostAppCacheQuota()`.
This is emitted once during WebView global initialization if `WebViewCacheSizeLimitDerivedFromAppCacheQuota` flag is enabled.
Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.CacheQuotaSize
histogram.summary:
Records the result of `StorageManager.getCacheQuotaBytes()` after WebView startup. The value denotes the amount of cache quota that was allocated to the app by the framework.
This is logged only once per session in a delayed background task approximately 5 seconds after WebView completes its main startup tasks. The measurement may be expensive, so it is only performed if the WebViewRecordAppCacheHistograms feature is enabled.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.CacheSize
histogram.summary:
Records the result of `StorageManager.getCacheSizeBytes()` after WebView startup. The value denotes the amount of cache that the app is currently using.
This is logged only once per session in a delayed background task approximately 5 seconds after WebView completes its main startup tasks. The measurement may be expensive, so it is only performed if the WebViewRecordAppCacheHistograms feature is enabled.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.CacheSize{ExceedsOrWithin}Quota
histogram.summary:
Records by how much the cache size {ExceedsOrWithin} the cache quota alloted to the app by the framework.
This is logged only once per session in a delayed background task approximately 5 seconds after WebView completes its main startup tasks. The measurement may be expensive, so it is only performed if the WebViewRecordAppCacheHistograms feature is enabled.
Only recorded in AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Callback.Counts
histogram.summary: Records the invocation count of WebView callbacks. Starting with M117, records shouldInterceptRequest counts.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.BindServiceTime.{Result}
histogram.summary:
Time taken by the bindService() call to bind to the component provider service in EmbeddedComponentLoader.doConnect() (via the connect() method), where the bind was {Result}.
The doConnect() call may happen on the UI thread or the thread pool, which may have different thread priorities. WebView backgrounds to the thread pool if the WebViewConnectToComponentProviderInBackground feature is enabled.
Only emitted for Android WebView, emitted at most once per session during Chromium startup. Neither a failure or success histogram will be emitted if there are no active component loader policies.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.CPSDirectorySize
histogram.summary: Size on disk taken by the ComponentsProviderService serving directory. This is logged once per run of the update job in AwComponentUpdateService.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.CUSDirectorySize
histogram.summary: Size on disk taken by the AwComponentUpdateService directory. This is logged once per update job in AwComponentUpdateService.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.GetFilesDuration
histogram.summary: Duration of ComponentsProviderService getFilesForComponent request. This method retrieves FileDescriptors for an installed component. This is logged at the end of every request the service receives.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.GetFilesResult
histogram.summary: Logs the result of ComponentsProviderService getFilesForComponent request. This method retrieves FileDescriptors for an installed component. This is logged once for every request the service receives.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.ProviderConnectUiTime
histogram.summary:
Immediate UI thread time spent running or posting EmbeddedComponentLoader.doConnect() (via the connect() method).
Does not measure any other UI thread component loading work outside of the doConnect() call. However, the doConnect() call may perform synchronous invocation of callbacks if backgrounding is disabled and service binding fails.
If backgrounding is enabled, binding is offloaded to a background thread and this histogram will only measure the cost of posting a task. Even if service binding fails, callbacks posted back onto the UI thread are not measured.
Comparing background vs non-background only indicates the amount of synchronous work immediately shifted off of the UI thread during connect(), but is not a direct indication of overall performance improvement or UI thread work reduction.
Only emitted for Android WebView, emitted at most once per session during Chromium startup. Backgrounding in WebView is enabled via the WebViewConnectToComponentProviderInBackground feature. This histogram will not be emitted if there are no active component loader policies.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.ResultsReceived
histogram.summary:
Time between calling EmbeddedComponentLoader.connect() and the final component result being received, at which point the component provider service is unbound.
Note that this time will not be dedicated to components processing. Additionally, as components are processed sequentially on the UI thread, this will include processing time for earlier components, but not the last component.
Only emitted for Android WebView, emitted at most once per session during Chromium startup. This histogram will not be emitted if there are no active component loader policies or some failure occurs before the last result is received.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.SafeModeActionExecuted
histogram.summary: Whether a SafeMode action was executed by Component Updater services. This is logged whenever a nonembedded Component Updater service checks whether SafeMode is enabled.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.UnexpectedExit
histogram.summary: Whether AwComponentUpdateService quit unexpectedly on the previous run. This might indicate a crash occurred during the previous job. This is logged once per run of AwComponentUpdateService.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.UpdateJobDuration
histogram.summary: Duration of AwComponentUpdateService update job. This job is responsible for updating and installing components. This is logged once per run of the job.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ComponentUpdater.UpdateJobFilesChanged
histogram.summary: How many components were updated by AwComponentUpdateService update job. This is logged once per run of the job, and is capped at 1000.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.ForceDarkBehavior
histogram.summary: Records WebView force dark behavior settings on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.ForceDarkMode
histogram.summary: Records WebView force dark mode settings on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.InDarkMode
histogram.summary: Records if WebView applies the algorithmic darkening on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.InDarkModeVsLightTheme
histogram.summary: Records if the application has light theme and if WebView applies the algorithmic darkening on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.InDarkModeVsNightMode
histogram.summary: Records if the application is in the night mode and if WebView applies the algorithmic darkening on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.LightTheme
histogram.summary: Records if the application has light theme on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.NightMode
histogram.summary: Records application's night mode bit related to android.content.res.Configuration.UI_MODE_NIGHT_MASK on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.NightModeVsLightTheme
histogram.summary: Records if application is in night mode and if it has light theme on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.PageDarkenedAccordingToAppTheme
histogram.summary: Records WebView is darkened or not when the prefers-color-scheme is set to dark according to the app theme not FORCE_DARK_AUTO setting. This histogram is recorded on main frame's color scheme inferred for every committed navigation.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.PrefersDarkFromTheme
histogram.summary: Records if WebView shall set prefers-color-scheme to dark according to app's theme after FORCE_DARK_AUTO fails. It is recorded on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.PrimaryTextLuminanceVsLightTheme
histogram.summary: Records if the application has light theme and if its theme's textColorPrimary attribute is light on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DarkMode.PrimaryTextLuminanceVsNightMode
histogram.summary: Records if the application is in night mode and if its theme's textColorPrimary attribute is light on each main frame navigation entry committed.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.AppLaunch
histogram.summary: Records the number of times the developer UI app was launched. This only ever logs the value "true" because we only care about the total count. This is logged in the developer UI app during Activity#onCreate.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.CrashList.CollectionState
histogram.summary: Records the state of crash collection, as seen by the developer UI. This is recorded when launching the crash UI, but only if the UI is not already showing an error message for another problem (ex. WebView package error). This only logs the first state we detect: ex. if the user has enabled crash reporting by opting in and also with the flag UI, this only logs the flag UI case.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.CrashList.CrashInteraction
histogram.summary: Records the user's interaction with crashes in the developer UI's crash list. Specifically, this tracks how the user interacts with the "hide crash", "upload this crash report" or the "file bug report" buttons and possible subsequent dialogs. Since the latter two buttons are connected (the user must upload a crash before they can file a bug report), we track interaction with both in the same histogram. This is recorded for each button press in the crash list and is not recorded if the user does not interact with any crashes.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.DeveloperModeEnabled
histogram.summary: Records whether or not WebView is starting up in "developer mode." This is a mode where the user has enabled debugging features through the WebView developer UI. This is recorded once during startup.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.FlagLoadingBlockingTime
histogram.summary: Records the time spent blocking WebView startup to load flags from the developer UI. This is recorded only once during WebView startup, and only if we've already detected developer mode is enabled (see "Android.WebView.DevUi.DeveloperModeEnabled").

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.FlagsUi.ToggledFromSearch
histogram.summary: This is recorded each time a user toggles a flag in the developer UI (changing a flag's state), and logs whether the user found this flag with the search bar ("true" means there was a non-empty search query). This is only recorded when the user toggles an individual flag through the Spinner dialog, not when they press the "reset all flags" button.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.FragmentNavigation.{NavType}
histogram.summary: Records the user's navigation to a Fragment. "FromIntent" tracks navigations triggered by an Intent (ex. navigating to HomeFragment on launch) and "NavBar" tracks user interaction with the bottom navigation bar. "AnyMethod" should be the sum of the other two. {NavType}

variant.name: FromIntent
variant.summary: User navigation through the bottom navigation bar

variant.name: NavBar
variant.summary: User navigation in response to an Intent

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.MenuSelection
histogram.summary: Records the user's selection in the developer UI overflow menu or action bar, recorded after each selection.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.NetLogsCalled
histogram.summary: Records the number of times the Net Logs were captured. This only ever logs the value "true" because we only care about the total count. This is logged in the nonembedded AwNetLogService when the net-logs flag is enabled and a webview is launched.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.SessionDuration2.{AndroidWebViewFragment}
histogram.summary: Records the time spent using a specific tool, from creation to destruction. {AndroidWebViewFragment}

variant.name: ComponentsListFragment
variant.summary: This is for the components list tool

variant.name: CrashesListFragment
variant.summary: This is for the crash list tool.

variant.name: FlagsFragment
variant.summary: This is for the flag modification tool.

variant.name: HomeFragment
variant.summary: This is for the home (default) page.

variant.name: SafeModeFragment
variant.summary: This is for the safe mode tool.

variant.name: Unknown
variant.summary: Unknown Fragment (the histogram may need to be updated).

histogram.name: Android.WebView.DevUi.ToggledFlagCount
histogram.summary: Records the number of flags we will toggle for this run of WebView. This is recorded only once during WebView startup, and only if we've already detected developer mode is enabled (see "Android.WebView.DevUi.DeveloperModeEnabled"). If developer mode is disabled, we will not toggle any flags through this mechanism.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.EnableTVSmoothing
histogram.summary: Logs whether we think the current device is a TV. If kWebViewUseRenderingHeuristic is enabled, this will also apply smoothing to rendered images. This histogram is intended to improve our TV detection over time by looking at the devices in each bucket. This histogram is logged once when setting up WebView's graphics context.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ForceDarkBehavior
histogram.summary: Records strategy to be used by force dark in WebView when setForceDarkBehavior API is called by the embedding application.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ForceDarkMode
histogram.summary: Records WebView's force dark setting and the UI's night mode when setForceDark API is called by the embedding application.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.GeolocationRetained.Granted
histogram.summary:
Records whether geolocation permission was granted by the embedded app if and only if the app also decided to persist the decision.
This histogram is emitted when the app calls the result callback for the permission prompt with a true value for the retain parameter.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.GeolocationRetained.ResponseTime
histogram.summary:
Records the response time from the embedding app to a onGeoLocationPermissionShowPrompt callback on responses the app decides to retain the value.
This metric will help us determine if apps are likely responding based on internal logic or if they are showing a UI prompt to the user, as the latter will be reflected in longer response times. Since geo-location requires an Android permission, we might see two peaks in this histogram for apps that only show the Android permission prompt. The aim of this analysis is to determine the impact of potentially removing the retain feature.
This histogram is emitted when the app calls the result callback for the permission prompt if the retain value is true.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.GetCacheQuotaSizeTime
histogram.summary:
Records the time taken to measure Android.WebView.CacheQuotaSize using `StorageManager.getCacheQuotaBytes()` in milliseconds.
This may be logged even if the measurement for Android.WebView.CacheQuotaSize fails.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.GetCacheSizeTime
histogram.summary:
Records the time taken to measure Android.WebView.CacheSize using `StorageManager.getCacheSizeBytes()` in milliseconds.
This may be logged even if the measurement for Android.WebView.CacheSize fails.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Gfx.HardwareDrawType
histogram.summary: Tracks invalidate and frame submission status for WebView hardware draw. Result is enum that represent three flags: did we called invalidate this frame, did renderer submitted compositor frame and whether DrawParams from Android HWUI changed. This is logged once per WebView draw functor call.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HistoricalApplicationExitInfo.Counts2
histogram.summary: Enumerates over the historical list of ApplicationExitInfo and their exit reasons for an application. Records the latest exit reason for the embedding application. Logged when the browser process is started.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HistoricalApplicationExitInfo.Counts2.BACKGROUND
histogram.summary: Enumerates over the historical list of ApplicationExitInfo and their exit reasons for an application. Records the latest exit reason for the embedding application, specifically when WebView's last recorded state before exiting was the background state. Logged when the browser process is started.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HistoricalApplicationExitInfo.Counts2.DESTROYED
histogram.summary: Enumerates over the historical list of ApplicationExitInfo and their exit reasons for an application. Records the latest exit reason for the embedding application, specifically when WebView's last recorded state before exiting was the destroyed state. Logged when the browser process is started.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HistoricalApplicationExitInfo.Counts2.FOREGROUND
histogram.summary: Enumerates over the historical list of ApplicationExitInfo and their exit reasons for an application. Records the latest exit reason for the embedding application, specifically when WebView's last recorded state before exiting was the foreground state. Logged when the browser process is started.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HistoricalApplicationExitInfo.Counts2.STARTUP
histogram.summary: Enumerates over the historical list of ApplicationExitInfo and their exit reasons for an application. Records the latest exit reason for the embedding application, specifically when WebView's last recorded state before exiting was the startup state. Logged when the browser process is started.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HistoricalApplicationExitInfo.Counts2.UNKNOWN
histogram.summary: Enumerates over the historical list of ApplicationExitInfo and their exit reasons for an application. Records the latest exit reason for the embedding application, specifically when WebView's last recorded state before exiting was the detached state. Logged when the browser process is started.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HistoricalApplicationExitInfo.Delta2
histogram.summary: Tracks the deltas (in ms) between the current time of recording and the last time of recording historical application exit info data. Only recorded if the last time at recording was non-zero and there was some exit reason recorded. Logged when the browser process is started.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.HttpCacheSizeLimit
histogram.summary:
Records the per-profile HTTP cache size limit that will be used throughout this session.
This is emitted once during WebView global initialization.
Only emitted for AndroidWebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.InputStreamTime
histogram.summary: Measures how long InputStreams take from creation to completion. This is emitted for all streams whether they succeed or fail. This metric was expired between December 2023 and May 2024. Data from that period will be incomplete.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.isDebuggable
histogram.summary: Records the number of times the WebView is debuggable or not debuggable, if it is debuggable then also how it has been set set, whether it is from the app or from the OS or from calling setWebContentsDebuggingEnabled(true). This is logged each time the MetricsService uploads metrics. Warning: this histogram was expired from 2025-05-18 to 2025-07-25; data may be missing.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.JavaBridge.InvocationIsInPrimaryMainFrame
histogram.summary: Records whether an invocation of a JavaScript method exposed through WebView's Java Bridge happened on a page's main frame or one of its sub frames. Recorded for each invocation of such methods.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.JsInjection.RenderFrameCreatedTime
histogram.summary: The time it takes to execute JsCommunicationHost::RenderFrameCreated. Recorded whenever a render frame is created in a WebContents that has a JsCommunicationHost attached (in other words, in Android WebView).

histogram.name: Android.WebView.LoadUrl.FailureScheme
histogram.summary: Records the scheme for calls to loadUrl that have failed (they will have recorded Android.WebView.LoadUrl.Success == false). Logged once per call to loadUrl.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.LoadUrl.RejectedHeaderCount
histogram.summary:
This histogram records the number of HTTP headers that are silently rejected by the WebView.loadUrl API. The API will reject headers if the name or value contains any of NULL, CR, LF with an IllegalArgumentException. However, header names have more forbidden characters than just those three, and the API will silently discard those headers to maintain long-term compatibility.
The purpose of this histogram is to identify applications who rely on this silent rejection of invalid headers in order to determine the disruption caused if we change the API contract in the future.
This histogram logs the count of headers that are silently rejected.
The histogram will only be emitted if the application is setting at least one header, and will be 0 if no invalid headers were rejected. It will not be emitted if any headers were rejected due to the 3 characters mentioned above.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.LoadUrl.Success
histogram.summary: Records whether a call to loadUrl succeeds or not, with regards to whether NavigationController.loadUrl returns a non-null NavigationHandle. This is logged once per call to loadUrl.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.LoadUrl.UrlScheme
histogram.summary: Records the scheme for the URL loaded by a browser-initiated navigation. Specifically, this is the scheme of the URL passed to loadUrl() (and its overloads), postUrl(), and loadData() (this is implicitly "data:"). also records if this value is "empty", which means either null or "about:blank". This intentionally excludes loadDataWithBaseURL().

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.ApiStatusV2
histogram.summary:
Records the Media Integrity API Status set by the embedding application. This status can be different for different URLs, but this histogram just records the reported API status without any URL information.
This metric is logged when the API status for the source origin is checked. This is done during the initial call to supply a token provider to the Blink Renderer Extension.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.ContentBindingSizeLog2
histogram.summary:
Records the ceil(log2(x)) of the size of the provided content binding on a requestToken call.
Play restricts the length of the content binding to 500, but this histogram is recorded before calling Play, so any values higher that 9 would likely have led to a client error.
This histogram is recorded as an exact linear histogram with a max value of 32.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.GetTokenCumulativeV2
histogram.summary:
Counts the number of calls to 'requestToken' for a token provider. This metric is counted individually for each token provider, and is emitted when the request for a token is made.
The metric will show the usage pattern of token providers by individual clients, by showing how many times they are used by the client
As a cumulative value, this value is incremented and logged for each successive call. This means that when this histogram is logged for the Nth time, it will already have been emitted for all values [1 ... N-1]. Before analysing the histogram, it should be normalised by subtracting the raw count of the next higher bucket from the bucket count. The interesting value is "how far did the app get". By subtracting the raw count of N+1 from bucket N, you remove all the counts where the app continued to emit the next value in the sequence.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.GetTokenProviderCumulativeV2
histogram.summary:
Counts the number of times the WebView Media Integrity getIntegrityProvider method has been called by web content since the app loaded.
This metric will be used to analyse the usage pattern of the Media Integrity API in apps, specifically to understand if apps are causing multiple sessions to be created, or if apps are instead creating a single webpage that loads a single resource which instantiates the API once.
The metric is logged whenever a valid request is made from Web Content.
As a cumulative value, this value is incremented and logged for each successive call. This means that when this histogram is logged for the Nth time, it will already have been emitted for all values [1 ... N-1]. Before analysing the histogram, it should be normalised by subtracting the raw count of the next higher bucket from the bucket count. The interesting value is "how far did the app get". By subtracting the raw count of N+1 from bucket N, you remove all the counts where the app continued to emit the next value in the sequence.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.GetTokenProviderResponseTimeV2
histogram.summary:
Records the end-to-end time for a GetTokenProvider call to a successful response. This will be the time observed by a JavaScript client waiting for a new token provider.
This includes both responses served from the cache and responses that go to Play. This histogram is not logged if the call results in an error.
This histogram replaces Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.GetTokenProviderResponseTime by extending the range of valid values from 10 seconds to 3 minutes.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.GetTokenProviderStatus
histogram.summary:
Logs the status of calling the Play getTokenProvider API.
This histogram is logged on both successful responses and error responses.
The error enum corresponds to the StandardIntegrityErrorCode, but introduces an UNKNOWN_ERROR code to catch situations where the Play client library introduces a new error code.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.GetTokenStatus
histogram.summary:
Logs the status of calling the Play request token API on the StandardIntegrityTokenProvider.
This histogram is logged on both successful responses and error responses.
The error enum corresponds to the StandardIntegrityErrorCode, but introduces an UNKNOWN_ERROR code to catch situations where the Play client library introduces a new error code.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.GetTokenTime
histogram.summary: Records the time from the beginning of a getToken request to a successful response is returned to JavaScript.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.InvalidInteraction
histogram.summary:
Logs invalid calls from JavaScript to the Media Integrity API Java implementation.
This histogram will be used to understand the extend to which clients are bypassing the JavaScript client API and sending unexpected requests to Java.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.NonRecoverableErrorReason
histogram.summary:
Records the reason for returning a "Non-recoverable Error" from the Android WebView Media Integrity API, to aid in investigating why clients are seeing a relatively high proportion of this error code.
The histogram is emitted every time this error code is produced by the implementation.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.TokenProviderCacheEvictionsCumulativeV2
histogram.summary:
Counts the number of times the token provider cache size has been exceeded, or in other words how many times an existing token provider was evicted from the cache in order to make room for a new one. The purpose of this histogram is to measure the effectiveness of the current cache size parameter, and will help inform if it should be changed, by giving us a histogram of how much larger it should have been to avoid evictions.
This metric is logged every time a token provider is evicted.
As a cumulative value, this value is incremented and logged for each successive call. This means that when this histogram is logged for the Nth time, it will already have been emitted for all values [1 ... N-1]. Before analysing the histogram, it should be normalised by subtracting the raw count of the next higher bucket from the bucket count. The interesting value is "how far did the app get". By subtracting the raw count of N+1 from bucket N, you remove all the counts where the app continued to emit the next value in the sequence.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.TokenProviderCacheHitsCumulativeV2
histogram.summary:
Counts the number of times a cached token provider is returned in response to a request from web content.
This metric will help gauge the effectiveness of the token provider cache, especially if the cache size is changed in the future. It serves as a way to measure the savings on requests to Play caused by the cache.
The metric is logged when a cached token provider is found in the cache.
As a cumulative value, this value is incremented and logged for each successive call. This means that when this histogram is logged for the Nth time, it will already have been emitted for all values [1 ... N-1]. Before analysing the histogram, it should be normalised by subtracting the raw count of the next higher bucket from the bucket count. The interesting value is "how far did the app get". By subtracting the raw count of N+1 from bucket N, you remove all the counts where the app continued to emit the next value in the sequence.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.TokenProviderCacheMissesCumulativeV2
histogram.summary:
Counts the number of cache misses for the token provider cache in an application.
This metric will help gauge the effectiveness of the token provider cache, especially if the cache size is changed in the future. It serves as a way to measure the savings on requests to Play caused by the cache.
The metric is logged when a cached token provider is not found the cache.
As a cumulative value, this value is incremented and logged for each successive call. This means that when this histogram is logged for the Nth time, it will already have been emitted for all values [1 ... N-1]. Before analysing the histogram, it should be normalised by subtracting the raw count of the next higher bucket from the bucket count. The interesting value is "how far did the app get". By subtracting the raw count of N+1 from bucket N, you remove all the counts where the app continued to emit the next value in the sequence.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.TokenProviderCreatedCumulativeV2
histogram.summary:
Logs how many times a new TokenProvider is created by Play.
This metric will show how many different token providers are requested from Play. With the token provider cache in place, this count is expected to be lower than GetTokenProviderCumulative.
This metric is logged when a provider is returned from Play.
As a cumulative value, this value is incremented and logged for each successive call. This means that when this histogram is logged for the Nth time, it will already have been emitted for all values [1 ... N-1]. Before analysing the histogram, it should be normalised by subtracting the raw count of the next higher bucket from the bucket count. The interesting value is "how far did the app get". By subtracting the raw count of N+1 from bucket N, you remove all the counts where the app continued to emit the next value in the sequence.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.TokenProviderCreationTimeV2
histogram.summary:
Records the time from requesting a new token provider from Play to receiving a successful response. This histogram is not emitted if the call results in an error.
This histogram replaces Android.WebView.MediaIntegrity.TokenProviderCreationTimeV2 by extending the range of valid values from 10 seconds to 3 minutes.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Memory.FunctorReclaim.OtherPrivateDirty
histogram.summary: Reports the app's "other private dirty" memory usage after some time in background. Collects the same data as Memory.Experimental.Gpu2.OtherPss, with the same caveats. Due to these, this should not be relied on to get accurate estimates of memory usage or deltas, but mostly used as a signal in Finch experiments. This is intended to evaluate the impact of draw functor reclaim.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Memory.FunctorReclaim.OtherPss
histogram.summary: Reports the app's "other PSS" memory usage after some time in background. Collects the same data as Memory.Experimental.Gpu2.OtherPss, with the same caveats. Due to these, this should not be relied on to get accurate estimates of memory usage or deltas, but mostly used as a signal in Finch experiments. This is intended to evaluate the impact of draw functor reclaim.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.MixedContent.Mode
histogram.summary: Records the mixed content mode set when an app uses the WebSettings.setMixedContentMode API.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.NonAppUid
histogram.summary: Records the type of UID that WebView is running as if it's not a standard application UID. This is recorded once during WebView startup on SDK30+ devices.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.NonEmbeddedMetrics.HistogramRecordAge
histogram.summary: Records the time interval between when a histogram is recorded in a non-embedded WebView process and when it's actually sent to the UMA API in an embedded WebView. This is recorded during WebView startup for each histogram retrieved and replayed successfully from WebView non-embedded metrics service.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.NonEmbeddedMetrics.NumHistograms
histogram.summary: Records the number of histograms received from WebView's non-embedded histogram service. This is recorded once during WebView startup, after retrieving histograms from the service (if the proto can be parsed).

histogram.name: Android.WebView.NonEmbeddedMetrics.ParsingLogResult
histogram.summary: Records whether metrics parsing from file in non-embedded histogram service was successful. It's recorded during service startup by adding it to records list. It captures the most recent file parsing result for the last service launch before the client connects to the service.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.NonEmbeddedMetrics.TransmissionResult
histogram.summary: Records whether metrics transmission from the non-embedded histogram service was successful. This is recorded once during WebView startup, after retrieving histograms from the service.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnGeolocationPermissionsShowPrompt.Granted
histogram.summary:
Records whether geolocation permission was granted by the embedded app.
This histogram is emitted when the app calls the result callback for the permission prompt.
Note: This histogram was not recorded correctly prior to M133.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnGeolocationPermissionsShowPrompt.ResponseTime
histogram.summary:
Records the response time from the embedding app to a onGeoLocationPermissionShowPrompt callback. This metric will help us determine if apps are likely responding based on internal logic or if they are showing a UI prompt to the user, as the latter will be reflected in longer response times. Since geo-location requires an Android permission, we might see two peaks in this histogram for apps that only show the Android permission prompt.
This histogram is emitted when the app calls the result callback for the permission prompt.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnGeolocationPermissionsShowPrompt.Retain
histogram.summary:
Records whether the app indicated that geolocation permission decision should be retained by WebView.
This histogram is emitted when the app calls the result callback for the permission prompt.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnPermissionRequest.Granted
histogram.summary:
Records if the permissions requested by the web contents were granted by the embedding app. We only record this histogram if the app responds, so it will not contain any default implementation results. The intention of the histogram is to understand how apps interact with the current permission APIs.
This histogram is emitted when the app calls either the grant or deny callback method.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnPermissionRequest.RequestedResourceCount
histogram.summary:
Records how many resources are in a callback to onPermissionRequest. The onPermissionRequests callback method supports requests for more than one resource at a time, and requires that the app grants all permissions, otherwise the whole request is denied. This histogram will help us understand how often apps actually see more than a single resource in a request, to help us plan a new permission solution.
This histogram is emitted when the WebChromeClient.onPermissionRequest callback is invoked by WebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnPermissionRequest.RequestedResources
histogram.summary:
Records which resources are in a callback to onPermissionRequest. The histogram is a sparse histogram and records the set of resources as a bitfield, which is how it is also represented internally.
The onPermissionRequests callback method supports requests for more than one resource at a time, and requires that the app grants all permissions, otherwise the whole request is denied. This histogram will help us understand which resources are requested together, to help us plan a new permission solution.
This histogram is emitted when the WebChromeClient.onPermissionRequest callback is invoked by WebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnPermissionRequest.ResponseTime
histogram.summary:
Records the response time from the embedding app to a onPermissionRequest callback. This metric will help us determine if apps are likely responding based on internal logic or if they are showing a UI prompt to the user, as the latter will be reflected in longer response times. Since video and microphone requires an Android permission, we might see two peaks in this histogram for apps that only show the Android permission prompt.
This histogram is emitted when the app calls either the grant or deny callback method.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OnRenderProcessGoneResult
histogram.summary:
This captures two pieces of information about renderer crashes: did the app developer handle the renderer crash to recover and what type of crash was this? This is recorded once each time the renderer process dies unexpectedly, and is logged after we have notified the app via the onRenderProcessGone() callback.
Prior to M99, this histogram did not distinguish between crashes vs. kills if the renderer crash was handled by the app. Warning: this histogram was expired from 2024-06-21 to 2025-09-08; data may be missing.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OptionallyBlockableMixedContentLoaded.Mode
histogram.summary: Records the mixed content mode set when an app loads optionally blockable mixed content (images, audio, or video). This histogram is logged on page load, once per subresource (i.e. a single page load can cause multiple records if the page contains multiple mixed content subresources).

histogram.name: Android.WebView.OriginsVisited
histogram.summary: Measures the count of distinct http and https origins visited per day in WebView. The purpose of this metric is to slice it by package name to help characterize the usage of that package.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.PrimaryCpuAbiBitness
histogram.summary:
Primary bitness of the bundle. This may be different from bitness of Browser. On WebView, Browser always follows bitness of the app, whereas Renderer follows bitness of the bundle (provided that such bitness is supported, so look at it in combination with CpuAbiBitnessSupport).
This is recorded every time a metrics log is created.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Profile.Prefetch.QueuedPrefetchExecutionDelay
histogram.summary:
The delay between when an application starts a prefetch request on a background and when that prefetch actually executes on the UI thread.
This is recorded every time WebView sends a prefetch request to the prefetch infrastructure inside of //content, it is not recorded for prefetches that are deemed as duplicate (or error out) and thus never reach //content.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ProfileWasCreatedByAsyncStartup
histogram.summary: A profile can be created from several code paths, including the AsyncStartupWebView API. This histogram specifically records when ProfileStore.getOrCreateProfile() is triggered by that startup path.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.RegisterResourcePathsAvailable2
histogram.summary: On Android V and above, this histogram logs whether the registerResourcePaths method is available once per startup after startup completes. It will be unavailable if the OEM has disabled the flag that gates the API. If we get an error during checking the flag value, that is logged too. A value of null means we encountered an error.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.RegisterResourcePathsTimeTaken
histogram.summary: On Android V and above, this histogram logs how long it takes to check the state of the registerResourcePaths flag once per startup during startup.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.RendererLibraryPrefetchMode
histogram.summary:
The app-controlled RendererLibraryPrefetchMode that is set when preparing to launch a renderer process. If the application somehow sets an unrecognised mode it is treated and logged as the Default case.
Emitted once per renderer startup by the browser when computing renderer process command line args. Only emitted for Android WebView. Only emitted when the WebViewConfigurableLibraryPrefetch feature is enabled.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.RestrictedContentBlocking.ApiCallMatchesDiskCache
histogram.summary:
Records whether the SafeBrowsingClient.getSupportedThreatTypes API call returns a result which matches our disk cache. This does not record the actual value of that call: a log of "true" means that the return value matches the disk cache and a log of "false" means that the disk cache didn't match.
This histogram is recorded when the task completes, which can be on either success, failure, or timeout.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.RestrictedContentBlocking.GetSupportedThreatTypes.CallDuration
histogram.summary:
Records the duration of the call to SafeBrowsingClient.getSupportedThreatTypes during the flow to determine if restricted content blocking should be enabled.
This histogram is recorded when the task completes, which can be on either success, failure, or timeout.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.RestrictedContentBlocking.GetSupportedThreatTypes.Result
histogram.summary:
Records the result of the call to SafeBrowsingClient.getSupportedThreatTypes during the flow to determine if restricted content blocking should be enabled. It will log success/failure/timeout.
This histogram is recorded when the task completes, which can be on either success, failure, or timeout.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SafeMode.ActionName
histogram.summary: Records which SafeModeAction was executed. This is recorded once during WebView startup and only if SafeMode is enabled (see "Android.WebView.SafeMode.SafeModeEnabled").

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SafeMode.ExecutionResult
histogram.summary: Records whether SafeMode was able to execute all the specified SafeMode actions or if it encountered an error. This is recorded once during WebView startup and only if SafeMode is enabled (see "Android.WebView.SafeMode.SafeModeEnabled"). If multiple fixes have different statuses, then this will log a single status in the following precedence: a. Unknown error b. Action failed c. Unrecognized action d. Success (If all actions were successful).

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SafeMode.QueryAndExecuteBlockingTime
histogram.summary: Records the time spent blocking WebView startup to both retrieve the list of SafeMode actions from the SafeModeService and to execute those actions. This is recorded once during startup only if SafeMode is enabled (see "Android.WebView.SafeMode.SafeModeEnabled"). This can be interpreted as the additional startup cost caused by enabling SafeMode.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SafeMode.ReceivedFix
histogram.summary: Records whether or not the WebView nonembedded service receives a SafeMode fix configuration. This is recorded once for each SafeMode config the WebView receives. This only ever logs true since WebView won't need to log anything when safemode is not activated. This is only relevant for the app recovery activation pathway.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SafeMode.SafeModeEnabled
histogram.summary: Records whether or not WebView is starting up in SafeMode. This is a mode where WebView takes extra steps during startup to reduce the risk of starting in a bad state. This is recorded once during WebView startup, regardless of whether SafeMode is enabled.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SaveState.Size
histogram.summary: Recorded whenever an embedder calls WebView#saveState, it records the size of that state in KB. The size isn't expected to exceed 1MB, as that is the limit for Android saveInstanceState.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ScheduleOnVizAndBlockTime
histogram.summary: Records the total time spent running a blocking task in TaskQueueWebView::ScheduleOnVizAndBlock(). This is recorded only on devices that support high resolution timers.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SecureCookieAction
histogram.summary: Records the action WebView took (if any) to "fix up" secure cookies for backwards compatibility.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SendBrowsingIntent
histogram.summary:
Records whether WebView handled a navigation by sending a browsing intent or not. The default behavior is to send a browsing intent for navigations and redirects, but this behavior is disabled if the application provides a WebViewClient of any kind.
The aim of this histogram is to determine if any applications use the default behavior.
This histogram is emitted when WebViewClient.shouldOverrideUrlLoading is called.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SetAcceptThirdPartyCookies
histogram.summary: Records whether third party cookies are being accepted following every Android API call, initiated by the hosting Android app, to CookieManager.setAcceptThirdPartyCookies().

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SetLayoutAlgorithm
histogram.summary: Records the layout algorithm requested in each call to WebSettings.setLayoutAlgorithm().

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.Async.CallbackLeakedWithoutResponse
histogram.summary: Whether the network request was intercepted asynchronously by the embedder of Android WebView. Intercepted requests are requests for which the asyncShouldInterceptRequest() callback returned a non-null response. This is logged each time the asyncShouldInterceptRequest() callback API is not invoked. This histogram was added in M136.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.DidIncludeMultiCookieHeader
histogram.summary:
Logs whether the application used the option to provide multiple Set-Cookie headers through WebResourceResponseCompat.
The histogram aims to track adoption of the new API to provide response cookies through shouldInterceptRequest.
Logged when the application responds to shouldInterceptRequest calls for either the WebView or service workers with a non-null response.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.DidOverride
histogram.summary: Whether a WebViewClient passed into setWebViewClient has overridden the shouldInterceptRequest method. Recorded when setWebViewClient is called.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.GetCookieHeader.PostMojo.TimeToRun
histogram.summary: Records the total time spent processing work to provide cookie headers to apps. This is recorded when WebViewInterceptedCookieHeader is enabled and after the mojo call returns with the cookie jar contents. This is recorded on all devices.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.InterceptDuration
histogram.summary: Measures the total time for shouldInterceptRequest in WebView, from the time the invocation is posted to the worker thread pool, until the response is posted back to the IO thread.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.IsRequestIntercepted
histogram.summary:
Whether the network request was intercepted by the embedder of Android WebView. Intercepted requests are requests for which the shouldInterceptRequest() callback returned a non-null response. This is logged each time the shouldInterceptRequest() callback API is invoked by WebView.
Not all requests will result in the callback being invoked, and thus the histogram will not be emitted in these cases. Some non-exhaustive edge cases include post-redirect requests not invoking the callback, and callbacks being triggered by non-network requests, such as data URIs.
This histogram was added in M116. Prior milestones logged "Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.InterceptionType2", however that histogram further broke down the "intercepted == true" case by which URL scheme was used for the URL.
Warning: this histogram was expired from 2024-06-13 to 2025-04-14; data may be missing.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.IsRequestSkipped
histogram.summary:
Whether WebView skipped running shouldInterceptRequest because the embedder hadn't overridden it (and hadn't provided the async version either).
This is logged in the shouldInterceptRequest flow before jumping onto the background thread.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.ShouldInterceptRequest.SetCookieHeader.TimeToRun
histogram.summary: Records the total time spent processing work to update the cookie jar. This is recorded when WebViewInterceptedCookieHeader is enabled and a set-cookie header is provided by a site embedded in the app. This is recorded on all devices.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SingleOrMultiProcess
histogram.summary: Records whether WebView is being run in a single process or multi-process. This is recorded each time logs are uploaded. This is used as a dashboard filter.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SitesVisitedWeekly
histogram.summary: Measures the count of distinct sites visited per week in WebView. This is recorded at the time of a navigation when stored hashed site navigations are older than a week. The purpose of this metric is to slice it by package name to help characterize the usage of that package. This histogram uses eTLD+1 as the definition of a site.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CheckNeedsPost.CalledOnUiThread
histogram.summary:
Reports whether or not `checkNeedsPost` (https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:android_webview/glue/java/src/com/android/webview/chromium/SharedWebViewChromium.java;l=208;drc=6712edb4e0491c96b69c7346ac278e5c093b6584) is called on the Chromium UI thread.
Conditions for recording this metric: Chromium is initialized and AwContents is not null.
`checkNeedsPost` is called by various WebView APIs.
Only recorded on Android WebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CheckNeedsPost.IsChromiumInitialized
histogram.summary:
Reports whether or not `checkNeedsPost` (https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:android_webview/glue/java/src/com/android/webview/chromium/SharedWebViewChromium.java;l=208;drc=6712edb4e0491c96b69c7346ac278e5c093b6584) is called before Chromium is initialized or not.
`checkNeedsPost` is called by various WebView APIs.
Only recorded on Android WebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.ChromiumInitTime.AsyncToSyncSwitchReason2
histogram.summary:
For asynchronous initialization, this metric tells us the callsite that caused us to switch from a previously scheduled or running async startup, to a synchronous startup.
This metric is only recorded for async startup and upon successful completion of the initialization process.
The older version of this histogram (Android.WebView.Startup.ChromiumInitTime.AsyncToSyncSwitchReason) used a less granular callsite enum. If any WebView instance methods or static method was the callsite, we couldn't know which exact method it was since it was grouped together as the same callsite. This issue is fixed in this histogram.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.ChromiumInitTime.LongestUiBlockingTaskTime{StartupMode}
histogram.summary:
For synchronous WebView initialization, this value measures the entire duration of running StartupTasksRunner's tasks together without yielding the UI thread, and will equal the "Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.StartChromiumLocked" histogram. For asynchronous initialization, it measures the longest task run by StartupTasksRunner.
This histogram is recorded in the last step of chromium init and so, is not recorded when init does not complete for any reason or if init had been completed in previous runs.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.ChromiumInitTime.StartupMode
histogram.summary:
Records the completion sequence of the WebView's Chromium initialization, indicating whether startup was fully synchronous, fully asynchronous, or a hybrid approach.
This metric is only recorded upon successful completion of the initialization process.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.ChromiumInitTime.WallClockTime{StartupMode}
histogram.summary: The wall clock time it takes to start up Chromium. This is different from ("Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.StartChromiumLocked") because for async startup, it includes the time spent in-between startup tasks.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CookieManagerThreadingCondition
histogram.summary:
Describes whether the default profile's cookie manager was accessed (gotten) before the Chromium UI thread looper has been set and, if so, describes the combination of the looper associated with the first cookie manager access and the looper set for the UI thread.
This is recorded once during WebView process global startup when the UI thread is set.
Only recorded on Android WebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.AssetsAddTime
histogram.summary:
The total time to add WebView assets to AssetManager. Reported on S+.
This task is performed and measured in the framework.
This time is included in `Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.TotalFactoryInitTime`.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.CreateContextTime
histogram.summary:
The total time to create the WebView APK context. Reported on S+.
This task is performed and measured in the framework.
This time is included in `Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.TotalFactoryInitTime`.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.FirstInstanceAfterGlobalStartup
histogram.summary:
How long it takes to initialize the first WebViewChromium instance in the case where we have already finished the process-global browser startup: ("Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.StartChromiumLocked") was already complete and did not need to be performed during the instance initialization.
This is recorded separately as it is significantly faster than the "FirstInstanceWithGlobalStartup" case, but slower than the "NotFirstInstance" case.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.FirstInstanceWithGlobalStartup
histogram.summary:
How long it takes to initialize the first WebViewChromium instance in the case where we had to also do the process-global browser startup: ("Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.StartChromiumLocked") had not yet run and was performed during the instance initialization.
This is recorded separately as it is significantly slower than the "FirstInstanceAfterGlobalStartup" and "NotFirstInstance" cases.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.GetClassLoaderTime
histogram.summary:
The total time to create the WebView ClassLoader. Reported on S+.
This task is performed and measured in the framework.
This time is included in `Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.TotalFactoryInitTime`.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.GetProviderClassForNameTime
histogram.summary:
The total time taken by `getWebViewProviderClass` method (https://cs.android.com/android/platform/superproject/main/+/main:frameworks/base/core/java/android/webkit/WebViewFactory.java;l=270;drc=61197364367c9e404c7da6900658f1b16c42d0da) in the framework. Reported on S+.
This task is performed and measured in the framework.
This time is included in `Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.TotalFactoryInitTime`.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.InitReason2
histogram.summary:
Records the reason for initialization (startChromium call), such as creating a WebView instance, calling a static method through getStatics() or other static methods.
The older version of this histogram (Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.InitReason) used a less granular callsite enum. If any WebView instance methods or static method was the callsite, we couldn't know which exact method it was since it was grouped together as the same callsite. This issue is fixed in this histogram.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.NativeLoadTime
histogram.summary:
The total time to load the WebView native library for the first time. Reported on S+. This also includes the time taken for processing relocations using the relro sharing mechanism.
This task is performed and measured in the framework.
This time is included in `Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.TotalFactoryInitTime`.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.NotFirstInstance
histogram.summary:
How long it takes to initialize a subsequent WebViewChromium instance. This will be recorded once for each instance created, other than the first to be created in the current process.
This is recorded separately as it is significantly faster than the "FirstInstanceWithGlobalStartup" and "FirstInstanceAfterGlobalStartup" cases.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.Stage1.FactoryInit
histogram.summary:
How long it takes to run WebViewChromiumFactoryProvider.initialize(). This does not count the time spent beforehand in WebViewFactory in the Android framework, which first has to load the WebView code and do some basic setup before initialize() can be called.
This will be recorded once per host process since the initialization is process-global.
The "Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.TotalFactoryInitTime" histogram measures the entire duration from when WebViewFactory.getProvider() is first called until the WebViewChromiumFactoryProvider is fully initialized and should be preferred for most purposes, but is only recorded on Android S+ devices, so this older metric is retained for now to allow "fair" comparisons with Android R and earlier.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.Stage2.ProviderInit.Cold
histogram.summary:
How long it takes to initialize a WebViewChromium instance in the case where we had to also do the process-global browser startup: ("Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.StartChromiumLocked") had not yet run and was performed during the instance initialization.
This is recorded separately as it is significantly slower than the "Warm" case, and can only occur the first time that a WebViewChromium instance is created. However, it's possible for browser startup to already be complete before the first WebViewChromium instance is created, in which case the "Cold" case will not be recorded during this session.
The newer histograms FirstInstanceAfterGlobalStartup, FirstInstanceWithGlobalStartup, and NotFirstInstance should be preferred for most purposes as they correctly reflect that there are three distinct cases here rather than only two, but the older histograms are retained for now to allow "fair" comparisons with builds that predate the newer ones.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.Stage2.ProviderInit.Warm
histogram.summary:
How long it takes to initialize a WebViewChromium instance in the case where we have already finished the process-global browser startup: ("Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.StartChromiumLocked") was already complete and did not need to be performed during the instance initialization.
This is recorded separately as it is significantly faster than the "Cold" case. However, it's possible for browser startup initialization to already be complete before the first WebViewChromium instance is created, in which case the first instance will be recorded as a "Warm" case, even though it is expected to be slower than subsequent instances, resulting in this metric being bimodal.
The newer histograms FirstInstanceAfterGlobalStartup, FirstInstanceWithGlobalStartup, and NotFirstInstance should be preferred for most purposes as they correctly reflect that there are three distinct cases here rather than only two, but the older histograms are retained for now to allow "fair" comparisons with builds that predate the newer ones.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.StartChromiumLocked{StartupMode}
histogram.summary:
For synchronous WebView initialization, this value measures the entire duration of running StartupTasksRunner's tasks together without yielding the UI thread, and will equal the "Android.WebView.Startup.ChromiumInitTime.LongestUiBlockingTaskTime" histogram.
For asynchronous initialization, it measures the cumulative duration of each task run by the StartupTasksRunner on the UI thread. This reflects the total time StartupTasksRunner's tasks block the UI thread. It does not measure the wall clock time from the start of the first task to the end of the last task.
This histogram is recorded in the last step of chromium init and so, is not recorded when init does not complete for any reason or if init had been completed in previous runs.
This histogram is of special interest, do not change its semantics or retire it without talking to the owners first.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.TotalFactoryInitTime
histogram.summary:
The total time to initialize WebViewChromiumFactoryProvider. Reported on S+.
This measurement is different from Stage1.FactoryInit as it takes into account time spent in framework. Does not overlap with Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.Stage2.* measurements.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.CreationTime.waitForUIThreadInit
histogram.summary:
Records how long it took to wait for the UI thread before running startChromium. Only recorded if startChromium was posted as a task.
Recorded in M125+.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.IsUiThreadMainLooper
histogram.summary:
Reports whether or not the Chromium UI thread is the Android main looper. Recorded once during WebView process global startup.
Only recorded on Android WebView.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.Startup.NonblockingServiceConnectionDelay.{ServiceName}
histogram.summary: Records the delay between calling Context#bindService until the ServiceConnection#onServiceConnected is called. This should give an idea of how long it takes for nonembedded service connections to be established and capture any regressions in this. In the case when a service connection is dropped and then reconnected by the system, the histogram is only recorded for the first connection. Warning: this histogram was expired from 2023-09-01 to 2025-07-29; data may be missing.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SupervisedUser.UrlCheckResult
histogram.summary: Records whether a given URL is allowed to be loaded by the current device user. This is based on a call to GMS Core, which checks if the url is allowed. This is recorded during each URL load, however only for the resource types which undergo this type of URL check.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SupervisedUser.UrlCheckTime
histogram.summary: Records the time taken to return from the call to GMS Core that checks if a given URL is allowed to be loaded by the current device user. This is recorded during each URL load, however only for the resource types which undergo this type of URL check.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SupervisedUser.UrlCheckTime.FirstRequest
histogram.summary: Records the time taken to return from the call to GMS Core that checks if a given URL is allowed to be loaded by the current device user. This metric is only recorded on the first call to GMS Core. This is recorded only for the first URL load, and only for the resource types which undergo this type of URL check.

histogram.name: Android.WebView.SupervisedUser.UrlCheckTime.SubsequentRequest
